name: Overrun
description: A creature can try to force its way through a hostile creature's space by overrunning it. The creature makes a Strength (Athletics) check contested by the hostile creature's Strength (Athletics) check. The overrunning creature can use its action or bonus action to attempt the overrun.

mechanics.onSuccess: The overrunning creature can move through the hostile creature's space once this turn
mechanics.onFailure: The overrunning creature's movement is stopped. It cannot move through the hostile creature's space.
mechanics.sizeAdvantage: The overrunning creature has Advantage on the check if it is larger than the hostile creature. The overrunning creature has Disadvantage if it is smaller.
mechanics.movement: Moving through the hostile creature's space still costs movement as normal. The hostile creature's space is not difficult terrain for this movement.
limitations: The creature can only move through the hostile creature's space once per overrun attempt
The hostile creature does not move; only the overrunning creature passes through
This does not provoke opportunity attacks by itself (though leaving the hostile creature's reach afterward might)
A creature cannot end its turn in another creature's space

interactions: Strength-based characters (Barbarians, Fighters, Paladins) excel at overrunning due to high Athletics modifiers
The Athlete feat and Expertise in Athletics significantly improve overrun success rates
This provides an alternative to the Disengage action for moving past enemies, but requires a contested check
Using a Bonus Action for overrun preserves the creature's Action for attacking, making it efficient for breaking through battle lines
Enlarge/Reduce can change the size category, affecting the Advantage/Disadvantage on the contested check
This pairs well with the Charger feat for creatures that want to move through enemy lines and still attack
